change_to_sparseGP(num_inducing)[source]¶

Changes standard GP estimation to sparse GP estimation

param num_inducing:
 number of inducing points for sparse-GP modeling
change_to_standardGP()[source]¶

Changes sparse GP estimation to standard GP estimation

plot_acquisition(filename=None)[source]¶
Plots the model and the acquisition function.
if self.input_dim = 1: Plots data, mean and variance in one plot and the acquisition function in another plot if self.input_dim = 2: as before but it separates the mean and variance of the model in two different plots
Parameters:filename – name of the file where the plot is saved
plot_convergence(filename=None)[source]¶
Makes three plots to evaluate the convergence of the model
plot 1: Iterations vs. distance between consecutive selected x’s plot 2: Iterations vs. the mean of the current model in the selected sample. plot 3: Iterations vs. the variance of the current model in the selected sample.
Parameters:filename – name of the file where the plot is saved
run_optimization(max_iter=None, n_inbatch=1, acqu_optimize_method='fast_random', acqu_optimize_restarts=200, batch_method='predictive', eps=1e-08, n_procs=1, true_gradients=True, save_interval=5, report_file=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

Runs Bayesian Optimization for a number ‘max_iter’ of iterations (after the initial exploration data)

Parameters:
  • max_iter – exploration horizon, or number of acquisitions. It nothing is provided optimizes the current acquisition. :param n_inbatch: number of samples to collected everytime f is evaluated (one by default).
  • acqu_optimize_method –

    method to optimize the acquisition function -‘DIRECT’: uses the DIRECT algorithm of Jones and Stuckmann.

    -‘brute’: Run local optimizers in a grid of points. -‘random’: Run local optimizers started at random locations.

    -‘fast_brute’: the same as brute but runs only one optimizer in the best location. It is used by default. -‘fast_random’: the same as random but runs only one optimizer in the best location.

  • acqu_optimize_restarts – numbers of random restarts in the optimization of the acquisition function, default = 20. :param batch_method: method to collect samples in batches -‘predictive’: uses the predicted mean in the selected sample to update the acquisition function. -‘mp’: used a penalization of the acquisition function to based on exclusion zones. -‘random’: collects the element of the batch randomly
  • eps – minimum distance between two consecutive x’s to keep running the model
  • n_procs – The number of processes used for evaluating the given function f (ideally nprocs=n_inbatch).
  • true_gradients – If the true gradients (can be slow) of the acquisition ar an approximation is used (True, default).
  • save_interval – number of iterations after which a file is produced with the current results.
  • report_file – name of the file in which the results of the optimization are saved.

GPyOpt.core.optimization module¶

GPyOpt.core.optimization.estimate_L(model, bounds, storehistory=True)[source]¶

Estimate the Lipschitz constant of f by taking maximizing the norm of the expectation of the gradient of f.

GPyOpt.core.optimization.estimate_Min(model, bounds)[source]¶

Takes the estimated minimum as the minimum value in the sample. (this function is now nonsense but we will used in further generalizations)

GPyOpt.core.optimization.fast_acquisition_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, model, method_type, X_batch=None, L=None, Min=None)[source]¶

Optimizes the acquisition function using a local optimizer in the best point

GPyOpt.core.optimization.full_acquisition_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, model, method_type, X_batch=None, L=None, Min=None)[source]¶

Optimizes the acquisition function by taking the best of a number of local optimizers

GPyOpt.core.optimization.mp_batch_optimization(acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, n_inbatch)[source]¶

Computes batch optimization using by acquisition penalization using Lipschitz inference.

Parameters:
  • acquisition – acquisition function in which the batch selection is based
  • d_acquisition – gradient of the acquisition
  • bounds – the box constrains of the optimization
  • acqu_optimize_restarts – the number of restarts in the optimization of the surrogate
  • acqu_optimize_method – the method to optimize the acquisition function
  • model – the GP model based on the current samples
  • n_inbatch – the number of samples to collect
GPyOpt.core.optimization.optimize_acquisition(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, X_batch=None, L=None, Min=None)[source]¶

Optimization of the acquisition function

GPyOpt.core.optimization.predictive_batch_optimization(acqu_name, acquisition_par, acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, n_inbatch)[source]¶

Computes batch optimization using the predictive mean to obtain new batch elements

Parameters:
  • acquisition – acquisition function in which the batch selection is based
  • d_acquisition – gradient of the acquisition
  • bounds – the box constrains of the optimization
  • acqu_optimize_restarts – the number of restarts in the optimization of the surrogate
  • acqu_optimize_method – the method to optimize the acquisition function
  • model – the GP model based on the current samples
  • n_inbatch – the number of samples to collect
GPyOpt.core.optimization.random_batch_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, n_inbatch)[source]¶

Computes the batch optimization taking random samples (only for comparative purposes)

Parameters:
  • acquisition – acquisition function in which the batch selection is based
  • d_acquisition – gradient of the acquisition
  • bounds – the box constrains of the optimization
  • acqu_optimize_restarts – the number of restarts in the optimization of the surrogate
  • acqu_optimize_method – the method to optimize the acquisition function
  • model – the GP model based on the current samples
  • n_inbatch – the number of samples to collect
GPyOpt.core.optimization.wrapper_DIRECT(f, bounds)[source]¶

Wrapper for DIRECT optimization method.

GPyOpt.core.optimization.wrapper_lbfgsb(f, grad_f, x0, bounds)[source]¶

Wrapper for l-bfgs-b to use the true or the approximate gradients. :param f: function to optimize, acquisition. :param grad_f: gradients of f. :param x0: initial value for optimization. :param bounds: tuple determining the limits of the optimizer.
